description: China’s share of world GDP rose from 2% in 1980 to 19.24% in 2019. As one of the leading forces in urbanization in the developing world, China's urban population rate increased from 17.92% in 1978, to 60.3% in 2019.
Shenzhen, the one pioneer city of China, serves as one of the best examples of the urbanization in developing countries.
Shenzhen is located in the south of China. It is a coastal city neighboring Hongkong, covering 1997.3 square kilometers of land.
The story of growth started four decades ago. Shenzhen was a small fish town in Guangdong Province, with only 310K residents
Three years after the Cultural Revolution, Shenzhen was promoted by Deng Xiaoping. Its partial districts became the first experimental Special Economic Zone (SEZ) in China.

1988, over-the-counter stock market (OTC) appeared in Shenzhen. It was later officially recognized as Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 1990.

In 1990, the first McDonald's in mainland China opened in the Shenzhen Special Economic Zone.
It is the one of the world's fastest growing cities in 20th century and early 21st century.
In 2010, the Shenzhen SEZ expanded from its four out of nine districts to the whole city. And, China surpassed Japan and became the world's second-biggest economy.
2018, it was the first time Shenzhen’s GDP has exceeded its neighbour Hongkong.
Today, Shenzhen has the highest GDP per capita in the nation. It also has become the most densely populated urban region in China and 5th in the world, with 6484 population per km².
Shenzhen is the epitome of the world factory of China, with the 3rd busiest container port in the world. Companies like Foxconn produce consumer electronics like the iPhone for the world every day.
With the name of China's Silicon Valley. It is the birthplace and headquarters for many of China’s top technology companies like Tencent, Huawei, and DJI.
This is a story of Shenzhen’s growth. But rapid growth comes with challenges.
In the next section let's take a study into Shenzhen's livability in three different aspects: Green Coverage, Hospital Accessibility, Crime and Safty.
